qas.question: What are three examples of fast food dishes in Portugal?

answers.text: Francesinha (Frenchie) from Porto, and bifanas (grilled pork) or prego (grilled beef) sandwiches

qas.question: Where does the Portuguese art of pastry have its origins?

answers.text: in the many medieval Catholic monasteries spread widely across the country

qas.question: What are the main ingredients used to make pastries in the monasteries?

answers.text: almonds, flour, eggs and some liquor

qas.question: What are two examples of Portuguese pastries?

answers.text: pastéis de Belém (or pastéis de nata) originally from Lisbon, and ovos moles from Aveiro

context: Typical fast food dishes include the <a0_0>Francesinha (Frenchie) from Porto, and bifanas (grilled pork) or prego (grilled beef) sandwiches<a0_0/>, which are well known around the country. The Portuguese art of pastry has its origins <a1_0>in the many medieval Catholic monasteries spread widely across the country<a1_0/>. These monasteries, using very few ingredients (mostly <a2_0>almonds, flour, eggs and some liquor<a2_0/>), managed to create a spectacular wide range of different pastries, of which <a3_0>pastéis de Belém (or pastéis de nata) originally from Lisbon, and ovos moles from Aveiro<a3_0/> are examples. Portuguese cuisine is very diverse, with different regions having their own traditional dishes. The Portuguese have a culture of good food, and throughout the country there are myriads of good restaurants and typical small tasquinhas.
